newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-SFE wheat bucks Chicago to firm in quiet mkt.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-SFE wheat bucks Chicago to firm in quiet mkt.

text.p: Australian wheat futures firmed in continued quiet trading on Thursday despite Chicago's fall on Wednesday, with the Australian Wheat Board's (AWB) pool price still the key to the market.
Only the near-term March 1997 contract traded, rising by A$4.00 to A$169.00 a tonne in five trades near the close.
Settlement prices (the mid-point between bid and ask quotes) rose by about A$3.00 a tonne for nearer-term contracts.
Ben Suttie, of C.A & L Bell Commodities Corp Pty Ltd, said slow futures trading reflected a cash market which was held up by the AWB.
Futures spreads were very wide, with differences of A$15.00-A$20.00 a tonne between bid and ask quotes.
Sellers were not interested because bids were seen as low, although bids (for example A$165.00 on March 1997 and A$150.00 on September 1997) were where the market should be, he said.
It was unclear when the AWB would close off its pool.

The board, which this week raised the pool price by A$3.00 to A$188.00 a tonne, owned the lion's share of Australia's 23 million tonne crop and closure of the pool should cause domestic prices to fall, Suttie said.
The AWB might keep the pool open for as long as possible, while keeping exports rolling, he said.
The general perception was that the last seven to 10 million tonnes of wheat might be hard to export, he said.
Australian domestic prices were at a significant premium to U.S. wheat now that Chicago had come off, he said.
